I love this game.  Admittedly I didn't know if I would like it because the theme seemed a bit girlish, but the gameplay is solid and the story is fun.  If you're a fan of Jane Austin novels, the plot has similar themes to Sense and Sensibility.  A girl trying to marry for love in a society where prudence and arranged marriage is the norm.  

RPG-style upgrades are rewards for well played hands.  Rewards provide special actions or abilities in game play.  A very enjoyable solitaire game.  I doubt I will enjoy old-fashioned solitaire after this.

39280902.review:
As one of the most common steam comment clichés go: I don't review much. I really don't. It is not something I am proud though. But in this case there is a burning sensation in me to write something about how a brilliant game has the weirdest reward system I've ever seen.

Before I start, I want to say the classical tone, music, visuals, smoothness are really great and the story is ok. I am looking forward to buy Shadowhand when its hype gets a little lower as I don't like paying that much to casual games.

Ok. Pardon my english. Here I go:

1. You can finish the game by pressing next card and doing nothing else.
Now this is insane. As the developers thought casual players get frustrated and downvote a game when they couldn't beat a level in a very short time (which I think is not true) they made Normal mode with every goal as optional. I am not a fan of Hard Difficulty levels but in this game I had to choose it. Otherwise you can just pass every goal and there is no indication on the map that a level's goals are passed. 

2. You can change difficulty during game.
You can start with playing Hard, got stuck in a level, change the difficulty to Normal, skip the level and go back to Hard. I really don't get it. This game is the only instance in a video game that I see is difficulty level is about fundamentals of reward system which I think is a pillar of gaming. It really should be about more jokers, less locks and it definitely should be unchangable after a new game started, so that you can know which difficulty you finished a game on. 

3. Some goals are really confusing.
I hated the level sets with goals of money. There is absolutely no way you can know how much you can gain in the next levels in a given set. So you can't plan, you can't save your jokers, you just don't know what will happen. 

4. When you press "quit hand" and come back, there is a surprise.
When you do this all the skill bars and jokers you get in that unfinished level come with you. Which mean you can quit and come back many times to make a full set of jokers to make it a perfect level 

5. The multipliers and perfect hand rewards are ridiculous.
Even if you make like a 20 combo you will get a multiplier of 2.2 - 2.7 which also doesn't multiply the perfect or good hand bonus of 250/500. So you can only multiply your money in a given hand which is 90-100 tops. You start a hand with 1.2 bonus with powerups. So 80x1.2=96, 80x2.5=200. You can see when you make a big combo there is only a difference of 100 gold when the money goals are usually 5000. Which means the only reason you might want a big combo is because it is in the goals. 

Also I like to add, when you need to make a big combo as most of the cards are upside down usually, you wouldn't know if starting using your jokers and skills is a good idea. Sometimes you finish a full set of jokers and couldn't make a 2.2.. It is just luck and I can understand that. But again maybe NOT setting goals of combos will help and the luck factor will still stay but with less frustration.

One last thing: I really wished the goals are level spesific and not for the whole chapter. That is also insane. When a chapter asks you to make 7 perfect hands, or a given amount of money, you really don't know when to start doing that or when to go relaxed for a hand. You can finish your goals in the first 6-7 hands and sit through 3-4 which is not so good. Also you can start relaxed and get really panicked in the last two. 

Developers, well done. But seriously you should study game concepts. I hope in Shadowhand it is better. I will see.

The first non-Windows solitaire I played and enjoyed (outside of everything put out by Tinytouchtales, but those are more solitaire-style than actual solitaire) was SOLITAIRICA. I bought that game and REGENCY SOLITAIRE this past Christmas. And though I really enjoy the goofy fantasy tactical battling of SOLITAIRICA, I gotta say, REGENCY is the more enjoyable game. 

Unlike SOLITAIRICA, if you lose, you don't have to start over from the very beginning. But there are enough challenges per level (and satisfying sound effects when you finish a card run) that make you want to play your best. And, of course, you want to see Bella get her HEA (Happily Ever After)!

Fun tableaus, soothing piano music, decent replayability and a languid BigFish-style vibe all make this a winner in my book.

35242110.review:
好吧，之所以玩这个纸牌游戏，是扫队列偶然看到类似作品名字带着“Solitaire”，一想这不Windows纸牌么，加入非扑克元素似乎有点搞头。正好手里有个类似的，玩一下好了。

结果有些尴尬。对比这酷炫的好评率，本萌妹感受到了来自世界范围的恶意。

我觉得好评能到这种程度唯一的原因就是，对休闲游戏来说没硬伤比什么都重要。但没硬伤的游戏就好玩吗？牺牲小我挖掘真相打了个全成就，特么hard难度成就还不向下覆盖我又打了一遍normal，我都被我自己感动了。

因为是休闲游戏，所以对Windows几个纸牌游戏的玩法进行简化没毛病，毕竟纸牌、空当接龙、蜘蛛纸牌对普通玩家来说还是有一定难度的，尤其是连翻三张牌、多花色这种高级规则也是相当反休闲。于是本作先把姿态降到最低，一次翻一张牌，取消花色作用；再把移牌部分去掉，只留下收牌来降低决策难度。问题来了，都特么简化了那这游戏玩个啥子哟？不慌，给你设计一批花式堆叠方式作为解谜元素，有没有很棒。剧透：[spoiler]没有。[/spoiler]

改变堆叠方式本身确实可以作为一个点来展开，但本作的问题在于，这方面的设计没能做到必要的合理性。老纸牌游戏固定的堆叠方式和移牌是游戏性所在，二者控制了随机性造成的影响。本作中取消移牌，加之堆叠设计欠推敲，以至于许多关卡受随机性干扰极大，比如两三张甚至一张牌压住了全部其他牌，或者牌序不好导致牌库无意义的浪费——翻不到关键牌就只能认输。此类情况在每局的中后期很容易出现，和“越到中后期局势越明朗、可发挥空间越大”的老纸牌游戏完全相反。

作者同样意识到了这个问题，然后就有了本作的微妙部分：技能、特殊牌和角色能力。简单概括它们的效果就是，给玩家改命的机会。就游戏体验来说，这些改命能力确实在一定程度上缓解了随机性失控，但无法在根本上解决问题，也没能引出有趣的玩法——看，这游戏好蠢，必须把那张牌毁掉才能继续下去。

最后终于全成就了，数十次失败紧接着零成本RETRY，唯一感想：没有什么是RETRY解决不了的，如果有，那就再RE一次。恰逢死磕本作期间断网半天，把纸牌、空当接龙、蜘蛛纸牌各玩了十几盘，一次翻三张，四花色，胜率在15%左右。我不确定这三个老游戏是否存在必死局，我只知道我似乎渐渐摸到了点窍门，这让我有点开心，而这也是本作没能做到的。

35143168.review:
A solid solitair game set in the regency period of England. 

The graphics and music provide a nice background to what is basically what the second part of the title says, solitaire. There are different layouts to the card placement which spices up variety and you gain access to various special abilities that allow you to do things such as randomly rearrange the stacks on the table, choose cards to discard from from the tops of face up piles, randomly remove a few cards etc. Getting consectutive matches without having to draw from the drawpile increase your combo counter, giving you bonue points depending on how long a run you can achieve. Wild cards can be picked up as you play either featuring a number or face value or a joker. You can play these at any time in order to keep a run going or get you out of a tricky spot. Each level also has various challenges guidlines you have to meet over the course of the 10 hands that compose each level. As the game goes on other twists will be thrown in, such as padlocks which lock down a pile until you can uncover the key to open it. At the end of each hand you are given a number of stars and a cash reward depending on how well you did that hand combo wise and whether you cleared the table. 

At the end of each level a story scene will play out and you can then spend your earned cash on upgrades for your ball room at home. Each upgrade increases the splendour of the ball room, but also adds to the power of your special abilities, making them recharge quicker or making them more effective when you use them.

Sound and music are quite pleasant.  The story cribs heavilly from Pride and Prejudice so don't expect too many surpises that way but it's still an ok distraction and the solitaire itself is fun enough that the story and presentation are just a pleasant icing on top of what is a solid solitaire game.

This is good casual fun and one of those good coffee break games. Playing a hand is only short so it's a nice way to unwind but also enganging enough if you want a distraction for an hour or two.

Overall, pleasant.

7 out of 10

33795774.review:
Si vous tournez sous [i]windows[/i], vous vous demandez certainement pourquoi vous lâcheriez des euros dans ce jeu, plutôt que de jouer à la version fournie gratuitement avec votre OS.
Bonne question...

Au départ, je pensais que l'unique valeur ajoutée de Regency Solitaire serait son enrobage esthétique et musical victoriens - tous deux particulièrement réussis et agréables, et qui peuvent certainement constituer un prétexte suffisant aux yeux de certain(e)s.
Or, son impeccable réalisation n'est heureusement pas l'unique proposition de ce jeu : il modifie pas mal les règles du solitaire basique en ajoutant quelques principes intéressants, qui rendent le truc finalement assez différent, et étrangement prenant et addictif.

Les règles originelles du solitaire n'autorisent que de "descendre" chaque colonne avec une carte de valeur inférieure en alternant impérativement les couleurs. Puis dans un coin à part, on remonte ensuite les cartes par ordre croissant et par enseigne à partir des As.

Regency Solitaire fonctionne différemment.

➤ Ici, on dégage les cartes définitivement à chaque correspondance valide : on oublie donc la séquence de "tri" finale à partir des As. Le but restant d'évacuer toutes les cartes du tableau.
➤ Pour ce faire, le jeu autorise de descendre [u]ou remonter[/u] sur une carte, [u]sans tenir compte de son enseigne ni même de sa couleur[/u]. [i](Sur un 5 rouge, on pourra donc placer un 4 noir comme un 6 rouge par exemple...)[/i]
➤ Les cartes sont disposées, empilées, et donc "bloquées" les unes sous les autres de façons variées et plus ou moins alambiquées selon les niveaux. De plus certaines sont retournées "face visible", afin d'éventuellement intégrer un zeste de stratégie dans les éventuels "combos" que vous échafauderez lors de vos suites de déblocages de cartes.
Car Regency Solitaire est bien un jeu à combos, où passé 5 cartes sans piocher dans le talon, un multiplicateurs de score augmentera en fonction de votre chaîne de cartes détruites.
➤ Contrairement au solitaire basique où on retourne indéfiniment le talon lorsqu'on finit par en voir le bout, Regeny Solitaire ne propose [u]qu'un seul[/u] égrainage du talon, et vous indique son nombre de cartes restantes. Quand elles sont épuisées la manche est terminée, et le jeu attribuera votre score et vos étoiles en fonction des cartes que vous avez (ou n'avez pas) supprimées:

✘ Aucune étoile gagnée au delà de 2 cartes restantes
★ 2 cartes restantes "Good"
★★ 1 carte restante "Great"
★★★ 0 carte restante "Perfect"

➤ Au delà de ces qualités de réussites motivantes, chaque partie vous rapportera de l'argent, qui permettra d'acheter les divers objets apparemment nécessaires à l’ascension sociale de "Bella". (Le scénario d'une niaiserie édifiante ravira éventuellement les fillettes en plein trip "bal" et "prince charmant" - pour les autres, un bouton "Skip Story" permet heureusement de couper court à cette intrigue particulièrement navrante - mais qui fait l'effort d'exister dirons-nous.)
➤ Chacun des 20 niveaux propose un joli décor différent, ainsi que des "objectifs", comme par exemple gagner un certain nombre d'étoiles, trouver un objet caché sous des groupes de cartes, gagner une certaine somme d'argent, etc... (sachant que chacun de ces niveau demandera de disputer plusieurs parties : à parir du niveau 4 on en joue 10 d'affilée).
➤ Des camées de "pouvoirs" à cooldown apparaissent au fil du jeu, permettant par exemple de détruire une carte, ou de mélanger le jeu pour éventuellement obtenir de nouvelles possibilités de combinaisons. Les objets achetés ont également divers effets concrets sur le jeu (révéler les cartes spéciales avec le curseur, augmenter l'efficacité d'un camée, réduire les prix, etc)
➤ Le jeu contient des cartes spéciales, comme les cartes "serrures", qui bien sur, ne s'ouvrent qu'avec les cartes "clé". Des cartes "jumelées" qu'il faudra toucher deux fois pour qu'elles disparaissent... Mais on trouve également des cartes bonus, conservables dans l'éventail pour les jouer n'importe quand. [i](Des jokers, mais aussi des cartes de "dépannage", (genre un 5 , jouable quand bon nous semble, mais SANS briser la précieuse chaîne de combo).[/i]

Concernant les éventuels reproches que je pourrais lui adresser (en dehors du scénar tout cucul dont j'ai déjà parlé), je dirai que le menu d'option est particulièrement rachitique, au point de ne même pas proposer de choix de résolution. On se retrouve d'ailleurs avec du 4:3 même sur un écran 16:9 avec deux bandes noires.
Le nœud de dentelle mauve sur les cartes "jumelées" est un peu trop discret : rageant de foirer une chaine de combo à cause de ça!
Enfin, les textes sont uniquement en anglais, mais difficile de lui reprocher ça, vu que ça ne nuit heureusement pas à la compréhension très intuitive des principes de jeux.

Bref, au delà de simplement proposer un très bel habillage visuel et sonore, Regency Solitaire insuffle quelques nouveautés amusantes et bienvenues au jeu initial, lui donnant un petit côté "arcade" (un peu dans la même ambiance que les "Montezuma" ou les jeux "King") carrément attrayant et addictif !
Si l'interface a clairement des relents de tablette, elle est franchement fonctionnelle et agréable à parcourir. Le jeu est hyper relaxant, les parties s’enchaînent vite, et les nouvelles règles s'harmonisent très bien.
Tout comme le système de bonus et de "camées de pouvoirs", suffisamment bien foutus pour être puissants, mais sans non plus déséquilibrer tout le jeu. De plus, le contenu est assez conséquent: en venir à bout prendra entre 12 et 15h ( si vous voulez du "perfect" partout + tous les succès).

Personnellement, je trouve que ça peut valoir le coup d'y mettre 4 ou 5€ si votre solitaire windows vous semble un peu trop dépouillé et austère, mais de là à y mettre 10 balles, ça me parait quand même surévalué...
C'est clairement un gentil petit jeu apaisant et distrayant, mais qu'il me semble nettement préférable de choper bien soldé ou en bundle. [i](Car malgré les indéniables valeurs ajoutées de ce titre, sa bonne durée de vie et sa finition irréprochable, des jeux de solitaire sympas et gratos, c'est vraiment pas ce qui manque sur le net).[/i]

other than this, which caused some frustration towards the end (though as I've read you can ignore level goals on easy and it'll still let you continue but that's not the same), it's an enjoyable experience and recommended if you're a fan of solitaire.

28929921.review:
A typical Golf Solitaire game that offers a relaxing aesthetic, nice art-style, a beautiful soundtrack and a mediocre story.

There is, [i]for the most part[/i], nothing better or worse about this Golf Solitaire game than any others, they are all the same in nature.
They usually offer some sort of 'item unlocking' system, typically these are items relevant to the in-game story that you purchase using money/points you earn for completing levels.
Once an item is purchased it gives you a unique feature, like a 'click-to-use' ability that removes 1 or 2 cards, or a passive ability like 3 more cards show face-up at the start of the hand etc...

There are a bunch of other things that 99% of all Golf Solitaire games have, if you've played one Golf Solitaire game you'll immediately recognize the same [i]features[/i] in the next Golf Solitaire game you play.

These, [i]at this point basically required[/i], features is what keeps a Golf Solitaire game fresh 5 hours down the line.

The way you make a Golf Solitaire game good is by having a beautiful soundtrack, a beautiful art-style, a relaxing aesthetic/atmosphere with a good story.

The game has a mediocre love-story set in the Regency era of England, again, nothing state of the art, if you've read 2 or 3 stories like this before you will not see something new and mind blowing.

The game is not hard in the sense of skill requirement, it is hard in the sense that it's luck-based.
The small amount of skill needed to play Golf Solitaire is something you pick up after 1 or 2 hours of playing it and is forever remembered by you, I.E you carry it over to all other Golf Solitaire games.
The same way if you make a cake once or twice and you make it again 1 year later, after 1/3 way through you start to remember how the recipe goes, you enter the flow of making the cake with seemingly no trouble as if you've made that particular cake a thousand times before.

This game also is an easy target for anyone looking to get 100% achievements, although that is arguably not a good selling-point.

I recommend this game for anyone who is into Golf Solitaire games, and to any new-comers I recommend you check out [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/38600/]Faerie Solitaire[/url] before and over anything else.

The presentation is top notch.  The problem is that there just isn't much to this game.  It looks nice, it plays nice, has good music etc.  But the target audience seems to be razor thin: Women who love Jane Austen, play Solitaire frequently, and actually have an use Steam.  Even then, the "Solitaire" in this game is basically just Pyramid, where you pick the cards that are one up or down from your current card, in a variety of layouts.  With power-ups.

There's the backbone of a very good game here, and like I said, what IS here is extremely well polished. Regency Solitaire is exactlly what says in the title, a card game that can be played by a single player. However it is nothing like spider or klondike (typically found in Windows, Gnome, KDE).

The game has a story. It's about a girl from the regency era that wants to be in high class parties and meet a suitable husband. Her family was rich but her brother inherited all the good and blew it up, so it's up to you to restore the prestige of the family and get the most handsome guy in town.

The game is basically a very simple solitaire. It's so simple that basically my strategy is clicking all cards until the level is over. Sometimes I win, others I do not. Either way it is easy to get a perfect score for every level by retrying enough. I'm sure there's a strategy to this game but honestly I don't even think, I just click every card because it's easier. It's a game with no real objective, you never really lose. Eventually you get powers that let your level finish faster. My strategy is to stock all those powers to finish the most difficult levels. The graphics are smooth and the music is okay but can get annoying. You can buy things to keep you stuck to the game. It's a nice addition.

The thing is I don't really know who the game is for. I guess young girls would like it, maybe. For me is a good game to make me sleep easier. The game is just so boring and mindless that it is very good for insomnia. Anyway it is a nice game to basically waste time. Don't except a strategy game because it's definitely not it.

25702622.review:
Charming little solitaire game with some extra tricks and Jane Austen flair

This game was made by just 2 people and there's no denying they are huge fans of the Jane Austen novels. The scenery, themes, characters and dialog feel like they're straight out of Pride & Prejudice or Mansfield Park, down to the use of the word "beau" (for a good looking bachelor).

I hadn't played solitaire before, but it's easy to pick up with this game and there's some tricks which you can unlock such as being able to take away the top card of a stack taking a peek at what's below the top card of your deck. The animations, backgrounds and portraits are done well. Can't say much about the music because I mostly listened to my own during my playthrough but the little I heard sounded very fitting.

My biggest complaint with the game is that each stage simply takes too long. Playing 5 instead of 10 rounds at each stage would have kept the experience less monotonous. The objectives don't really help here since they are mostly stuff that you'll be doing anyways and complement each other. I had also purchased all the upgrades and was floating lots of gold near the end. As you can see I spend around 9 hours completing the story line, but doing so in 4 would have felt less tiring.

My other complaint is that the story is too much straight forward in the sense that there isn't really any internal struggle for any of the characters. Bella's (main character) friends and relatives even encourage her to engage with the right guy. I disliked the puny and descriptive names like "Mr Bleakly". The idea of gathering accessoires to furnish up your room fits very well thematically though.

Fortunately the game doesn't fall into the trap of having the story make up all kind of excuses to play solitaire. It would have been really lame if every other scenario was along the lines of "Fine, you'll get to have your ball on our premises, *but only if you can handle 5 perfect rounds of solitaire". Instead the devs wisely decided to separate gameplay and story in this point.

All in all a pleasant experience. As long as you know what you're going into you should be fine. If you've never read Jane Austen than all the references will be mostly lost on you. Watch a video of some gameplay if you're undecided as of yet.

Mezzanotte è passata da poco, ma dato che non avevo sonno, decido di scaricarmi un giochino "da mezz'ora e poi nanna". Spulciando nella libreria, trovo questo titolo: Regency Solitaire che chissà da quale bundle lo avevo pescato e scelgo questo. Dopo pochi minuti per scaricare e installare il gioco, inizio a giocarci. Diciamo che quando ho riguardato l'ora s'erano fatte quasi le 4 del mattino :|

Regency Solitaire è un gioco dove nei panni di Bella (sì, c'è pure una storia), giochiamo a Solitario con le carte francesi: l'obiettivo del gioco è rimuovere tutte le carte dal tavolo (disposte in modo particolare) come in un solitario qualsiasi. Proseguendo con la storia sbloccheremo anche abilità e potenziamenti come il poter rimuovere fino a 2 carte a scelta oppure aumentare le probabilità di trovare Wild Cards.
Il gioco di per sé non è male, anzi l'ho finito e devo dire che è stata una piacevole sorpresa. Ci sono qualcosa come tipo 180 livelli, anche se a dirla tutta verso la seconda metà è subentrata la noia e l'unica che mi spingeva a finirlo era proprio per vedere come finiva la storia. 

Graficamente è abbastanza semplice, i disegni non sono malaccio e girerebbe pure su un tostapane. Menzione a parte per le musiche del gioco, veramente piacevoli.

Non è un gioco che consiglierei a prezzo pieno, ma se è scontato e vi piacciono i solitari, bhé un pensierino fatelo :P

25340400.review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title:[/b]  Regency Solitaire
[b]Developer:[/b]  Grey Alien Games
[b]Publisher:[/b]  Grey Alien Games 
[b]Genre:[/b]  Card Game

[h1]General Impression[/h1]
I never thought that solitaire, is the type of card game to which a new spin may be added. Then again, this title is far more than a simple solitaire game with a Regency Era (1795 – 1837) skin placed over it. Regency Solitaire is here to tell a story, one which isn’t half bad if you’re into Jane Austen’s style of writing (also known as “novels of manners”). Before I delve deeper into the card gameplay itself, I would like to point out that the beautifully drawn locations and characters would have surely benefited from some level of voice acting, which sadly isn’t present. That is the game’s sole con, as the rest of it is most pleasing given the small file-size. I admit that I seldom play cards and even less frequent have been my incursions into solitaire. I have to say, the game is wrongfully perceived by some as the bureaucratic time waster of choice. Regency Solitaire convinced me that there’s more to this card game than meets the eye. A progressive difficulty system and the presence of a tutorial, provided plenty of assistance. No glitches disturbed my gameplay and the inclusion of both Trading Cards and Achievements justify the price tag even more. If you’re into card games, Regency Solitaire shall not disappoint you.
 
[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Beautiful graphics and storyline.
+ Fully functional and competent card game.
+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- Repetitive musical score and no voice acting.

[b]Rating 8/10[/b]
 
[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews]Imperial Reviews[/url] and [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Cubbes]Cubbes[/url].[/quote]

25287827.review:
[i]“Bella a Mr. Bleakley? To nikdy!”[/i]

Regency Solitaire je karetní puzzle založené principu, který pochopí asi každý - z hrací plochy odebíráte karty, které sousedí s kartou na odkládacím balíčku. Za 6 můžete zařadit 4 nebo 5, za J 10 nebo Q..atd. Pokud se vám podaří navázat hodně karet za sebe, získávate komba, která multiplikují vaše skóre. Každé kolo se liší výchozím rozložením hromádek karet na stole. Svůj význam má i náhoda, protože karty jsou namíchané pokaždé jinak. Podobně jako u normálního Solitaire tak může dojít k tomu, že se vám sejde konfigurace, kterou nemáte šanci dohrát. To nicméně nevadí, v opakování kol jste omezeni jen vlastním časem ;-)

Hra má i příběh z období začátku 19. století… Nicméně vzhledem k tomu, že jsem nebyl schopen udržet pozornost při čtení konverzací, jsem autorům vděčný, že alespoň pojmenovali hlavní uchazeče o ruku hlavní hrdinky jasnými jmény: Když spolu soutěží “pan Bleakley” a “Lord Worthington”, víte jasně, kdo je klaďas a kdo záporak (a můžete příběh ignorovat, ehm). 

Regency Solitaire nabízí jednoduchou zábavu pro každého kdo si občas rád zahraje Solitaire. Nebráníte-li se výzvám, můžete na těžší obtížnost zkoušet dosáhnout (i za pomocí žolíků, nahrazujících chybějící karty) na velká komba. Poslední kola tak už umí být i trošku výzva. 

Za kolik stojí: 1€

Picked up this game in a recent Humble Bundle, although it hadn't even been added to it at the time of purchase.  It looks and plays like a F2P/P2W mobile throwaway game, but isn't (there aren't any in-app purchases or DLC or anything).  

I just finished it, playing a little over 14 hours over the last week or so.  In the credits, it says it was made by a 2 person husband and wife team.  It shows, but something about this game is bizarrely compelling.  Everything about it is so earnest, form the Jane Austen setting (with archaic dialogue for added atmosphere) to the game's title.  This is literally a solitaire game set in Regency England.  But the actual decks/card placement feels well designed, and even if the story is bare-bones and full of holes (and Austen stereotypes), its earnestness makes it enjoyable in a so-bad-it's-good way.

So I recommend this game, especially if you find it on sale or in a bundle.  And I hate Jane Austen novels.

25268776.review:
[b]A charming little title with flaws too big to overlook[/b]

[i]Regency Solitaire is not without it's merits. It is a relaxing little card-game which actually bothered to tell a story, looks good enough and has a great soundtrack. Sadly, it relies way too much on RNG and the gameplay itself is far too simplicistic too enjoy.[/i]

When you load up Regency Soiltaire for the first time, you will be almost overwhelmed by all the kitsch that literally slaps you in the face. It's not bad, however; it grows on you in a weird way and after the first few levels you won't mind the shamelessly ridiculous baroque atmosphere anymore. It's similar with the story - god, it's so simple, conciously archetypical and still you can't help to feel a weird sympathy for what's unfolding on your screen. You probably need to like the trashy kitsch-atmosphere or really love baroque, or you won't feel the same. Maybe it's just Stockholm Syndrome. All in all, it's not too bad and everyone purchasing this should already know what to expect after taking a short glance at the storefront.

Don't get fooled by the name - Regency Solitaire is not really Solitaire how you know it from your Windows-installations or Linux-repositories. There is no stacking of cards. Instead, you take cards from into your hand by clicking on it, but only if the card is exactly one value higheror lower than the current card on top of your hand. If there is no such card on the field, you draw one from a stack of cards. The game ends once the field or the stack is empty, the former is preferred. There a three abilities with a recharge and some special types of cards which bring a little bit of variety. Between sessions you spend the money you have earned while playing cards for powerups. 

All of this is really relaxing, because you just click, and click and click without having much to worry about. Most of the time the next step to take is absolutely clear, it is very rare that you have actually a hard time deciding between two options. That is my main gripe with the game: You have almost no influence over what outcome the round will have. As I have said, you almost never have a real choice. If you win or not, is mostly a question of what cards are in your stack and on the field. There are games in which it is almost impossible to win, then you hit the retry-button and make it in two minutes. Three powerups bring a little bit of spice in the game, but they reload so slow that you can use them only once per round anyway, so they don't matter too much. In the end, it's just a game against your own time, when you hit the retry-button for so long until you got a good result. [b]If I am missing some tactical depth here, let me know! I'd love to give it another try.[/b]

[i]tl;dr: Music is good, art is okay, plot and atmosphere are charming in a trashy way, but the gameplay is simple and relies so hard on sheer luck that I can not recommend it, especially for 10 bucks.[/i]

One word review : [b]Elegance[/b]

A solitaire game? Haven't played that since Win95...
A story about a girl wanting to marry some rich guy? Exactly [b]not[/b] my cup of tea.

Do not let its appearances deceive you, Regency Solitaire is a [b]finely crafted gem[/b] and one of the [b]most addictive and elegant games[/b] I have ever played.

Deceptively simple, the gameplay revolves around this precept : You flip a card, you then click any card on the board which is 1 unit of value higher or lower than your base card. That new card then becomes your base value. Repeat ad infinitum.

As the game progresses, you will unlock various bonuses which greatly facilitate gameplay and in my opinion somewhat makes the game a bit too easy, even on the hardest difficulty.

To be honest, I have skipped 95% of the story and the game doesn't force you to care about its narrative, which is a great sign of user convenience.

The polish on this game is where it counts, menu navigation is smooth, the sound effects are all satisfying and never grate on the nerves.

If you're looking for a card-based "puzzler", give it a go and then you too can try to convince everyone that this is the greatest thing ever.

That is what leaves me puzzled, aside from inclusion in an Humble Bundle, how can you promote this game to a wider audience? No idea...A true paradox.

25214796.review:
So... After Faerie Solitaire and Chef Solitaire, this is the third game I'm playing that bears the name 'Solitaire' and is actually a variation on Pyramid Solitaire with power-ups. I don't know which came first (probably yet another game?), and in casual games it's common to re-use proven techniques, but I'm still not comfortable with that. Okay, it's a 'husband & wife game', even though they credit a ton of Russian artists for the (admittedly beautiful) graphics, so I won't complain too much. At least the game has the decency to be twice shorter than the excrutiating Chef Solitaire.

It doesn't have voice acting though, which would have been nice, if only to make the story slightly more interesting. I'm very much full of love for Jane Austen's novels (okay, a couple movie/TV adaptations of Sense & Sensibility and Persuasion, and I've also watched Austenland... Does that count?), but I couldn't help but roll my eyes with all the clichés I found in the script. Well, at least it's not about a reality-TV-cook-show, which is always a plus.

I didn't care much for the music either. Repetitive, uninspired, only one level (halfway through the game) has a seemingly original track that's more pleasing to the ears. The graphics, as I said, are beautiful. The heroine reminds me of an ex, I don't know if that was a plus or a minus for me, but I'm not going to take that into account for my recommendation. (Yes, I'm a serious man with a serious recommendation system. That probably explains why I have so few friends.)

What else, then..? I think that the 'pyramid solitaire with power-ups' system is great, but all three games I played suffered from similar flaws:

- Very, very long, with the game divided into chapters that require specific results to move on to the next chapter. Failing to reach these goals forces you to restart the chapter from the start (usually 10 levels, which can be finished in less than half an hour... Still, you don't want to restart that, do you?) Really, that's tedious. Why can't I select a specific level to redo inside a chapter? Only Chef Solitaire allowed me to do that, IIRC.

- Boring story! Don't blame me, this matters to most people of taste. Otherwise, don't bother to add a story, thank you very much.

- Ungrounded love for card combos. Yes, they're cool. But requiring people to achieve a certain amount of combos in each chapter is tedious, because it removes the fun of solving a game and forces you to be careful about one more thing. Plus, there are levels where it's easier to make a combo, but the game doesn't tell you that.

- In fact it doesn't tell you much... There's a would-be tutorial, but it never explains plenty of things, such as: what if you fail one of your goals? Do you have to restart from scratch? How are score multipliers calculated? Some requirements involve reaching a certain multiplier, but doing multiple small combos seems to increase it randomly (or even not at all). That's just an example. The game basically assumes that you've played this kind of game for years already, and that you don't need rules. Yes, you do. Not everyone is a pyramid solitaire veteran. Me, personally, I'm a Spider Solitaire veteran. Perhaps tens of thousands of hours on the record. Yet I'm not expecting everyone to know every possible strategy to win a game.

- A complete and utter disregard for balancing difficulty. Solitaire games are random by nature, so the difficulty level is determined by the card layout. Some layouts are just hard to read (upside down cards, really?), or even just tricky (multiple cards on top of one another without any visual clues, thank you very much), but what really happens is that hands are so randomized, the final chapter was by far the easiest to me -- I didn't have to redo any levels in my first playthrough, or maybe just one, as opposed to at least 5 or 6 out of 10 in previous chapters. I retried it in normal mode, which only lowers requirements to pass a chapter, and had to restart 3 or 4 levels in order to get a perfect score (which I wanted everywhere). Still easier than previous chapters, but really, it shouldn't be harder than hard mode now, should it?

Okay, I'm done with the complaints.
Overall I did finish the game, and enjoyed it a lot more than Chef Solitaire, so I'm giving it a thumb up. But please guys, if you ever make another one... How about trying to give a story mode with predetermined cards, and then a 'free-roam' mode where you get random layouts and random card orders? That way you could balance the game more effectively.

25213246.review:
Ah, Regency Solitaire: a simple casual game that's up-down solitaire matching, similar to Faerie Solitaire and others in the genre, but: it's polished to a mirror sheen. The devs got everything right in this game, so let's go down the list.

Design: The gameplay is rock-solid. You've got the scattered piles of cards that you clear by matching cards either up one or down one in the hierarchy. (i.e. if you have to clear a ten, use a jack or a nine.) You make chains for combos and multipliers to your score, and that's all simple enough. The game mixes things up by adding wildcards (you can have more than one in stock, too!) and three powers. There's the cupid (remove a card), the shuffle (as it sounds), and the phoenix (remove two cards). You're at the mercy of the RNG for a good layout in a given hand, so these tools help get you out of those situations, and getting through hard levels often just means hoarding them so you can use them at strategic moments. There are additional upgrades you can purchase throughout the game, for extra undos or a power-up that will randomly remove extra cards at the beginning of a hand.

Also, there are locks on the piles - you need to clear royalty cards to get rid of them, or find keys in the cards to undo them. I love this! Adds a little more complexity to the game without making it taxing.

The game is structured so you play ten hands in a level, and the challenge comes from trying to meet chapter goals, like getting two perfect hands or a combo of ten cards. Standard fare for this genre, competently done.

Visuals/Sound: It's all in theme with the Regency style. Everything looks good, everything sounds appropriately Regency-era. No complaints here at all.

Plot: It's presented in a visual novel style, with little scenes playing between levels. It's a bit thin, but amusing to watch the tale of the young lady trying to woo her beloved while her brother gambles the family fortune away.

Essentially this is a fantastic game to use for unwinding, with a gentle plot and sumptuous visuals and gameplay that's simple but addictive. There are oodles and oodles of levels, a normal and hard mode, and it's a lot of bang for your buck. Check it out!

25180602.review:
A simple and forgiving solitaire clear-the-board game with a few extra additions. Reminds me a lot of Fairie Solitaire, though I haven't played that in a while. Story is mediocre, graphics and music are decent. You play as a daughter of a Victorian family and your brother Edward gambled away your family's money and you're also arranged to marry an unliked neighbor. Your story goes through how you marry upwards. It allows you to skip the story (via a button in cut scenes) if you prefer.

It uses the standard solitaire rule (you can only take cards from the playing area/tableau that are next in sequence to the one drawn from the stock/hand pile). Colors/suits don't matter. For example, if there's a 10 on top of the pile, you can only take a 9 or a jack. If there's an ace, you can only take a king or a 2. If you can't remove everything from the playing area before your deck/stock pile runs out, you lose.

There are two special blockers that stop you from interacting with piles in the playing area. Some piles have a lock card on top which you can't access until you find the key card (located somewhere in the playing area) and use it on the lock. There's a regal lock which can only be removed by taking a certain amount of J/Q/K cards off the playing area.

And sometimes cards in the playing area are tagged with a blue bow that show they need to be used twice to be removed from the board. The first usage removes the bow and the second usage removes it from the board as usual.

There are three special skills you unlock that can be used on a cooldown. One lets you remove a selected card, another shuffles the playing board, and the last randomly removes cards.

Wildcards are the 'Get Out of Jail Free' card of the game that allow you to brute force the game and combat bad RNG. You can randomly find them instead of regular cards while playing and then put them into your wildcard area (can store up to 11 for future use). When you use them, they take place of the active card on your deck/stock pile. So instead of waiting to draw the right card from the stock pile, you can use the wildcard to immediately start removing cards from the playing area. Since wildcards aren't refunded for retries you have to learn when it's better to go all-in for the high combo, when it's not worth using and when to cut your losses.

There are twenty levels. Each level has up to 10 stages and each stage is one 'game' of solitaire. You earn a maximum of three stars per stage for clearing all cards in a stage. You also earn gold based on how well you do that can be spent on items that make the game easier (better chance of finding wildcards, more undos, upgrading skills, etc.).

Goals for each level are to uncover an item (which is underneath cards on one of the stages), earn enough stars/perfect hands (max 3 stars per stage, 3 stars is a perfect hand), earn enough gold (based on how well you do & combo meter), and get a high enough combo/multiplier (which are linked). It's very forgiving because it allows you to redo stages so bad card RNG isn't so frustrating. If you take your time to clear every stage, the only difficulty is in getting a high combo which depends on card luck and usage of wildcards you've saved. There are little tricks you can do to make it easier to get a high combo (like going for it on stages with more exposed cards and setting up a long combo by intentionally removing/keeping certain cards on the board).

There are a couple quirks:
[list]
[*] Beating the game on Hard mode doesn't also give the achievement for Normal mode but you can replay the final level on Normal since you can switch difficulties at any time.
[*] From what I can tell, you can't see the 'How to Play' explanation from the main menu, you need to get into an actual level and then access the menu from there.
[/list]

I found it to be a decent time sink that wasn't very mind-intensive. Because it's very forgiving in retries it's not especially challenging. However, any hardcore mode would just mean grinding levels until you save up wildcards and replaying levels hoping for great RNG. Not a very appealing idea to me. I think casual difficulty suits this genre. If you've spent time playing solitaire when it came with Windows before Steam existed, you might enjoy this version of solitaire.

23288810.review:
Regency Solitaire is (unsurprisingly) a solitaire game with an over-arching storyline about arranging a ball for lead character Bella in order for her to win the heart of the man she falls in love with. The game was made by Grey Alien Games from Dorset, UK, and it is also set in England taking place at various locations such as London, Brighton, and Bath. There are 20 chapters, with 180 unique levels to play through. 

The game can be played in Normal or Hard mode. I'd personally recommend playing through in Normal mode first, before then playing through in Hard Mode. As you play through the game, you unlock certain things which make game-play easier, such as losing a card or two at the start of each level; being able to undo turns if you realise you've made a mistake; being able to shoot down cards that you can't match together with anything. 

To play the game you simply match a lower or higher card number onto your drawn card, so for example an Ace can be matched with a Two or a King; a Nine can be matched with a Ten or an Eight. 

Each chapter has a set list criteria to meet in order to progress onto the next chapter, such as having 6 'perfect hands' out of the 10 levels in the chapter, or getting a combo of 15 cards played at one time, etc. The upgrades that you get for the ballroom, which you buy using gold that you earn for completing a level, makes achieving these criteria much more straight forward, particularly in later levels. During play, you also find 'wildcards' that can be stored and played if you are struggling to make matches, or if you can see that just having that one additional card in play would enable you to make a bigger combo. 

The art style and music in the game really set the tone and style that the developer was going for, and it's very charming and faithful to the period in which the game is set. The storyline is a little cheesy certainly, but I found it rather charming and engaging and I actually wanted to know how the story developed and played out as I was playing. 

I finished this game doing a full play-through in Normal mode, then a full play-through in Hard mode in just under 15 1/2 hours. I managed to get all 17 of the achievements for the game in Steam also. I have heard a rumour to get the "Sumptuous Solitaire: Beat the game in Hard mode." achievement you only need to finish the last level on Hard instead of playing through the full game, but what fun is that!? 

This game is a charming and challenging solitaire game which I thought was a delight to play from start to finish. If you like card games with a bit of strategy to go along with the basic number-matching, this is definitely one to try.

Bought the game on sale for my girlfriend. She's into period pieces and Solitaire; seems like it'd just her cup of tea. And boy, was it. She rather enjoyed the game and after watching her play a few hands, I bought it for myself.

The game play is pretty classic Solitaire: in that you chain together cards in consecutive sequence in either ascending or descending fashion with the objective being to clear the board of cards. But unlike MS Solitaire, however, suit and color doesn't matter; all you need is the next card up or down. That is to say, a 4 or 6 can be place on a 5, Queen or Ace can be put on a King and so on. You play until you either clear the board or run out of cards in the deck.

Also unlike MS Solitaire, Regency Solitaire does not simply arrange its board into 7 columns increasing in size, but rather, the game arranges its cards into some very intricate stacks that definitely require a bit of thought and strategy. Not to mention, some of the arrangements are rather pretty in and of themselves. The game also provides you with power-ups and helper cards in the form of Jokers and wildcards. All of which can be unlocked via normal gameplay. They are unlocked using in-game currency earned simply by playing the game and are priced reasonably enough that you shouldn't have to grind chapters to save up enough cash. You can get through the game with nothing more than a little patience as failing to clear a hand has no penalty other than you not making any progress towards chapter goals. In fact, you can retry hands completely free and without penalty. The lavish settings combined with this unpunishing gameplay makes for a great way to unwind after a long day. In addition, the game is suprisingly well-polished with appropriate music, sound effects, and graphical effects in addition to the tight gameplay.

The complaints I can raise about the game are few and minor, in that they don't really affect the core gameplay at all. I do wish there was a way to view what static buffs you have after buying the item that provides it. I also found it odd that the little Eye icon in Bella's House does not really do anything... seems like it would have been a great place to add in a way to see what buffs you have purchased via a tooltip or something that appears when hovering over the particular item. I also think a way to turn them on and off would make for a nice, sort-of DIY difficutly slider, in addition to simply Easy and Hard. If expanded a little more, a bit more strategic depth could be added by limiting how many perks Bella could use at a time. but that might just be me trying to inject unnecessary mechanics into a game designed with ease and simplicity of gameplay in mind. The other thing I would have liked is if the chapters had more variety to their lengths. Each one being 10 hands after the third or so chapter gets a bit tedious towards the end. 

All said, definitely worth the sale price, but I would still recommend at the full price. It's well designed and well developed with tight and smooth gameplay. Good for hopping on for a few hands or for a lengthy binge.

Regency Solitaire is a nice, but challenging solitaire game with a Georgian era storyline. Bella dreams of hosting a ball of her own and meeting her true love. However, her brother, Edward, has squandered the family's fortune by gambling. Now it looks like her father is going to give her hand to their odious neighbor, Mr. Bleakly, since she has no money for a dowry. 

Play is quick and the game is addicting. As you finish chapters, you can buy items that serve as power-ups. There are ten hands per chapter. 

Pros: 
*  Graphics and music are very nice. Storyline is ok, but you can skip it. You can also make the chapter's scenes your desktop's wallpaper. 
*  Fairly challenging game play, including playing in either normal or hard mode.
*  Power-ups and wild cards make game play more interesting. Also Steam achievements.

Cons: 
*  While you can replay the current hand in a chapter, you can't go back to a previous hand in the same chapter.
*  If you get through a chapter and don't complete one of the tasks, it will ask you if you want to replay. If you do that, however, it wipes out the entire chapter. You have to start from the beginning of that chapter and play all ten hands again, which is annoying.

21240454.review:
An excellent solitaire game with a well thought out storyline placed strategically between "places" giving the gamer a mental break.  Set in the beginning of the Regency Period of England (1812) follow Belle through a matrimonial based societal season as she is pursued by one man but pursues her own dream of finding love and happiness with another man.  These short story breaks in the gameplay offer tidbits of what life was like during this period of history and the common places those of society went.  Bright and colorful artwork of each place added during gameplay as wallpapers.

Gameplay: Starts at three hands and increases to ten hands per place invited.  Every hand can be repeated, using retry, if the gamer wishes to achieve or needs to achieve a better score to reach the "local" goals. (Note: once the player moves on previous hands can not be repeated unless the player restarts that level.)   This particular retry feature comes in very handy when trying to achieve the 35 card combo, which as far as I can tell can only by achieved in two places (last chapter Belle's Ball, hand 7 or 10).  My best combo before Belle's Ball was 34 and I ran out of cards. So sad.

The player can have up to 11 "wild cards" and jokers can be used as any card which makes getting that elusive 35 card combo possible.  There are three "power-ups". 1) Cupid who shoots an arrow (2 when upgraded) to eliminate a single card on the playing field. 2) A fan used to shuffle the cards, and shuffle includes both the cards of the playing field and those remaining in stack.  Can be useful.  3) A fire phoenix that burns 2 (3 when upgraded) random playable cards of the playing field.  (Note: I do not recommend using any power-up when trying for the 35 combo since at most there are only 37 cards on the playing field.)

Just a few words on the card hands, some are very, very challenging.  One of the hardest hands I had only had about 16 cards on the playing field and about 28 cards in the stack.  The way the playing field cards were laid out overlapping one another and having multiple cards with ribbons (ribbons mean the player had to use that card twice) was quite the challenge to clear, and power-ups were certainly handy to have.

Overall, an addicting card game, that moves along rapidly though the levels, and becomes more challenging as the player moves through the story.

Regency Solitaire is a very good game.  I'm not going to bother describing the game, since its gameplay is obvious from the trailer and from other reviews.   I'll just list some positives and negatives.

Its core gameplay is similar to Fairway Solitaire's (originally made by Big Fish Games, but the PC version was made by Grey Alien Games, who also developed Regency Solitaire).  The addition of on-demand powers like the bow and arrow provide some strategic options lacking in Fairway Solitaire.   On the other hand, some mini-games like Fairway Solitaire's would have been nice.  However, I think it was a good decision by the developer to add powers instead of mini-games.  Mini-games did not add to the core gameplay of Fairway Solitaire.

There's something very addictive about finding long runs and continuing them with powers and saved cards.  

It has a good amount of replayability because it has multiple difficulty levels and the items you acquire can change the way you play.

I liked the wide variety of scenic backgrounds, but I do prefer shorter scenes: having to play up to 10 rounds just to see a few lines of dialogue sometimes did not feel very rewarding. 

I would have liked to see a way to compare scores with other Steam members, but I understand that this game is not just for Steam users.

17652746.review:
Regency Solitaire is a very nice, relaxing, charming, yet challenging game.  

The setting takes places during the Regency era in the United Kingdom - early 1800s. The Regency era is noted for its elegance, fine arts, and architecture. It also encompasses a time of social, political, and economic change.  This all is very nicely reflected in the game itself.

The game is centered upon a particular family within the Regency era, what each family member's role is, and how they handle, or mishandle, said role.  As the storyline continues throughout the game, the player learns a bit more about each family member.  

The artwork is absolutely gorgeous!!!  The music very pleasant and reminiscent of that time era.  You do have the capability to turn off the music, if it distracts you.  There are two different settings, normal and hard. You can go back and forth if you like. If a level is too difficult, you can change the setting to normal ... or vice versa if you feel you want a more challenging game. Two of the Steam achievements involve finishing the game on the Normal setting and also the Hard setting.  [Note: If you do not want to play the entire game over on Hard when you have already played it on Normal, you can click on the last 'pearl' of the game and just play that last level on hard to get that particular achievement.]

This is not your typical Solitaire game. This game involves the playing of cards in an ascending and descending order on top of the faceup card to be played off of ... until all of the cards have been removed from the tableau (the board).  Within each level, there are specific challenges/goals you work toward achieving. By achieving those goals, you earn money to purchase power-ups, and to also decorate the main character's home.  They go hand in hand. Further clarifying that, each power-up has it's place as a decorative piece within the home of Bella (the main character), and also becomes integrated into the card game itself for the player to use when needed. The power-ups replenish over time -- not by the clock but by subsequent cards played. There are also random 'wild cards' that, once found, are kept in Bella's fan in the lower right corner, to be played when needed. The power-ups and wild cards carry over from level to level if not used. 

If wild cards are used, you will come upon them again by continued play. Bella's fan can hold up to 11 wild cards -- from 'Jokers wild' to a specific card itself. There are no time restrictions, nor penalties.  The player plays at his/her own pace. For instance, if the player cannot complete the hand, has utilized the power-ups, and has used all the 'wild cards' they can use to keep that 'run' going, but cannot remove all the cards from the board by level end -- you earn no money, no achievements, but you are given an opportunity to retry that hand as many times as you like.  You also do not lose the power-ups, they simply replenish over time by each subsequent card played. However, if used, the 'wild cards' must be found again and will be displayed in Bella's fan for play.  The 'wild cards' are placed randomly throughout each hand.

There are several interesting additions in this game that I have not come across in other Solitaire games, which makes it that much more unique, challenging, and fun.  For example, some cards have big blue bows on them. What that means is that there are 'two' of that particular card on the board, right on top of each other and secured by that bow.  Sometimes, you will find that there are several sets of 'bowed' cards scattered about the board.  By clicking on the first bowed card in an ascending or descending order to be played off of the faceup card, that will utilize that particular card, leaving its double still on the board to be played when the opportunity presents itself ... but no longer 'bowed'. It has become its own singular card to be played. There is also a set of cards whereby one is a 'lock' and the other is a 'key'.  The player will find the key card through gameplay, click on it, drag it over to the lock, which then disposes of the 'lock and key' altogether, which in turn opens up that part of the board that was once blocked by the 'lock' card. Finally, there are also what is referred to as 'hidden cards' which I found even more challenging but fun, not a distraction at all! What happens is that on some of the boards, there is a card amongst the cards to be played whereby the player cannot tell if that is a 'stack' of cards or a 'singular' card on its own until it is clicked on to be played off of the face up card. 

If you've played 'Golf Solitaire' -- this game is similar to that.  You play in an ascending and descending order off the faceup card.  It's the additional goals, types of cards, etc., that makes this game so unique and so much fun!!  Please remember, there is no time limit nor penalties.  You can take as long as you like to study the board and play accordingly.  If it doesn't work to your advantage, the devs have integrated a 'retry' capability ... again, with no time limits nor penalties.  This game does not have to be rushed through or become stressful. In fact, it is quite enjoyable!  

And, yes ... the devs, Grey Alien Games, have also implemented Steam achievements and card drops!!!

I highly, highly recommend Regency Solitaire!!!!!

17628513.review:
Faerie Solitaire senza uova.

Un punticino in meno rispetto a quello, solo perchè la storia è di livello femminucciesco. Va bene per chi vede le soap opera con la principessina che ha come unico scopo della vita quello di fare un ballo con il principe azzurro.

Per fortuna il gioco è un solidissimo e curato passatempo.

AGGIORNAMENTO DOPO AVERLO TERMINATO AL 100% - CON UNA DESCRIZIONE PIU' COMPLETA
Mi è piaciuto ed è il tipico gioco di solitario alla Faerie Solitaire, in cui lo scopo e quello di eliminare tutte le carte dal campo di gioco ad una ad una utilizzando una carta del mazzo di valore immediatamente superiore o inferiore.

A complicare le cose il fatto che 

-sul campo di gioco le carte selezionabili sono limitate di numero, in quanto le altre sono inizialmente nascoste da quelle sovrastanti
-alcune carte sono eliminabili solo con una doppia selezione 

Il gioco è diviso in una serie di capitoli (non li ho contati, ma dovrebbero essere una ventina) uniti tra di loro da una trama che nemmeno la peggiore telenovelas argentina si azzarda a tanto per la vergogna.

Comunque, ogni capitolo è costituito da un gruppo di dieci solitari, per ognuno dei quali vengono assegnati tre compiti, ad esempio raccogliere un quantitativo minimo di soldi, fare un certo numero di combo, scoprire qualche oggetto nascosto dalle carte (ad esempio un ventaglio che serve alla sfigata della trama per conquistare il cuore del bello e riccone di turno che non dovrebbe cagarla, in teoria, invece la ama già dal primo dialogo, per cui tutto il resto della storia è privo di qualsiasi senso) e così via. Se alla fine dei dieci solitari non si raggiungono i tre obiettivi, non è possibile avanzare nella "storia", quindi verso i solitari successivi.

Inoltre la storia può essere affrontata in modalità normale o difficile: cambia la difficoltà nel raggiungere gli obiettivi, ma il gioco comunque rimane abbastanza semplice.

A facilitare le cose infatti vi sono carte speciali che permettono di continuare le sequenze quando in mano non si hanno carte per proseguire la combo attuale e tre mosse speciali che permettono 

-di eliminare 2 carte dal campo di gioco a scelta del giocatore
-di eliminare 3 carte in modo casuale
-di mischiare nuovamente le carte sul campo di gioco

a queste si aggiunge un'altra abilità (tutte le abilità si sbloccano durante la prima partita nella storia) che permette di vedere in trasparenza la prossima carta da utilizzare nel mazzo.

Le mosse speciali una volta usate non possono essere riutilizzate subito, ma solo finchè non vengono "ricaricate" con le mosse normale...

Alla fine in quasi 13 ore di gioco è possibile arrivare al 100% degli achievement. 

Un bel passatempo comunque.

Polished game by Jake & Helen. Very beautiful graphics and theme. Not very deep in strategy (I'm thinking strategy/war games to compare). Gameplay is much about spotting cards and then thinking which pile to choose. Sometimes there's only spotting the card. In a way it's some sort of mix between match-3 games and solitaire done well. 17393263.review:
Another solid entry in the "Faerie Solitaire" type of game.

This one is set in Regency England (early 1800s) and you will visit familiar settings such as Bath, London, and Brighton.  The dialogue even includes idioms of the time period, which was a nice surprise.

The gameplay is great, with some interesting layouts for the cards.  Later on there are locked sections where you need to get a key to turn over those cards.  Since it is luck-based there will be times you'll have to replay a hand.  But thankfully there are also special abilites you can use to help out in situations like that.  

There are 2 difficutly settings, one casual for easy play, and one with more requirements to win.  The story is the same for both.

Graphics are nice, with great details on some of the scenes.

Music is relaxing classical.

This game is shorter than other similar games I've played.  I have 15 hours and I played it through on easy and hard, with lots of replaying hands to get perfect scores.

17390840.review:
This game is way too addictive. 

I've had a fun time playing it. The story is adorable, the game is challenging, and the art is gorgeous. Anyone who is a fan of regency novels or solitaire games will get a kick out of this.

17369339.review:
Regency Solitaire ist feiner Zeitvertreiber und zu genau diesem Zweck kann ich das Spiel auch empfehlen. So ist ja auch mit dem alten Microsoft Solitaire. Spielerisch wird keine Offenbarung und keine Innovation geboten. Im Endeffekt orientiert man sich an den klassischen Strip-Mahjong Spielen die es in Japan zu Hunderten gibt. Ein bißchen Story, ein paar nette Bilder und fertig ist das Spiel. Natürlich wird hier nicht gestript, sondern man darf sich einer recht simpel gestalteten Romanze mit etwas Herzschmerz widmen. Gottseidank, gibt es einen Skip Story Button, wer aber will darf sich gerne an den Dialogen erfreuen.

Wie der Name schon sagt, geht es ansonsten um das Kartenstapel abräumen. Damit es nicht zu altbacken wirkt, hat man sich einige Neuerungen einfallen lasse: Blocker, die sich nur durch Bildkarten wegräumen lassen oder Schlösser für die der Schlüssel erst gefunden werden will. Damit der Spieler nicht überfordert wird, gibt es noch ein paar Hilfsmittel und Spezialkarten die als Platzhalter und Joker fungieren. Nach ein paar Stunden sollte man im Normalmodus durch sein. Auf Hard kann es etwas länger dauern. Ich habe aber keinen großen Unterschied feststellen können.

Wer also so etwas wie Regency Solitaire zum Zeitvertreib für ein paar Stunden sucht, muß sich nur entscheiden wieviel ihm der Spaß Wert ist.

17328138.review:
Regency Solitaire combines the great gameplay of the original Fairway Solitaire and adds on a delightful regency-themed setting. New rules and mechanics add more flavour to the game as you play, but never overcomplicate it, making it well-designed and fun for both casual players and those looking for a bit more challenge.

Plus you get to marry the man of your dreams and avoid the sleazy Mr. Bleakley by PLAYING SOLITAIRE.

If you enjoy playing Solitaire even slightly, then Regency Solitaire is a must-buy.

17322320.review:
Regency Solitaire is a totally charming take on the single-player card game by Grey Alien Games.  A variation on the golf solitaire play style, this fast-paced version of the classic game will have you addicted before you can say "tea and biscuits!"

Golf solitaire involves playing cards in ascending or descending order until all have been removed from the board.  There's a bit more to it than that, but it's a very easy to learn version of the game that will appeal to those looking for a more relaxing experience.  While there is indeed some thought needed in play, once you get the hang of things you'll be a solitaire pro in no time.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=486910736
The game is divided into 20 chapters in which you have between 3 and 10 tableaus (boards) to complete a set of objectives.  These objectives get progressively harder with each chapter, but are never unfair in their requirements.  As you successfully complete each tableau, you'll earn money to purchase power-ups that will help you clear cards much easier.  You may also bank up to 11 wild cards which can be used to extend combos.  Chaining combos is the meat of the game play as bigger chains increase your score multiplier, thus rewarding even more money at the end of each chapter.  Of course, luck will play a factor in the draw, with particularly bad layouts often requiring several retries if you don't have enough power-ups or wild cards to get through them.  But that comes with the territory in solitaire.  At least there are ways to overcome it here.

While there are several different versions of solitaire out there, this is the first Regency era themed game I have come across, and it's absolutely charming.  Everything in the presentation has an air of gentility to it, from the beautiful hand-painted artwork to the elegant music and charming character dialogue.  The simple yet enjoyable story that plays out between each chapter feels as if it was pulled right from a Jane Austen novel, which is a compliment in its own right.  Altogether, it's a pleasant experience that  will transport you to early 1800's England when elegance and sophistication was prized above all else.

If you are a fan of solitaire, I cannot recommend Regency Solitaire enough.  Between the enjoyable game play, amusing story and lovely presentation, there's very little I can complain about here.  I only wish it were a bit longer, as playing through Bella's tale of courtship was an absolute joy that didn't last nearly as long as I'd have liked.    

Bottom Line: Recommended to all solitaire and casual gaming fans.

17267253.review:
Update: I recommend watching [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yw1L2yKhzZY]MsCarsonelle's video[/url] to get the feeling of the game :)

A really addictive puzzle-ish card game. The objective is to get rid of (ideally all) cards on the desk, all of which are faced down except for those on the top. To do it, you start with a deck of cards from which you can draw. With the currently drawn card, you can collect a card from the desk that has one lower/higher value, making that your current card. By continuing collecting cards, you get combo multipliers and hence bigger score. The chain gets interrupted once you draw another card from the deck. Some levels also have special obstacles - locks for which you need to find a key-card on the desk, or royal-locks which require you to collect certain amount of Jack/Queen/King cards in order to unlock.
Simple enough to play in the morning, complex enough to wake you up :)

Each level consists of several desks you need to clear and has special goals. Those can be getting X perfect hands (leaving no cards on the desk), reaching a certain combo (chain of collected cards), getting high-enough multiplier (can be reached by multiple smaller combos), uncovering an item hidden under cards or getting enough starts throughout the level (3 stars for cleared desk, 2 stars for 1 card left, 1 star for 2 cards left, 0 stars otherwise).

To help with the goals, you can buy items. Those unlock by progressing the game, while you can buy them for your score. The bonuses vary from revealing certain cards on the desk to increasing the amount of Undo's to special abilities and upgrades. Special abilities consist of target-destroy (up to two) desk cards on top, shuffle all the cards and random-destroy (up to three desk cards on top).

Edit: I forgot to mention that there are also special blue cards, which you can collect and store. Those don't have any requirements to be collected nor played. You can use them in order to continue your collecting chain.

There're also two tiers of levels, easy and hard mode, where hard mode has higher challenges through the goals.

The art is nice and fitting, though the full-screen mode only stretches the game, making it feel... awkward.

There were some bugs forcing you to quit the game (and restart the hand), but I'm glad to say that those have been already fixed, and I didn't have to restart the game since. :)

17258374.review:
TL,DR: If you like Faerie Solitaire, there's not a lot of reasons why you shouldn't like Regency Solitaire. There's a bit of difference between the two, RS has power moves. The difficulty is, at least on hard mode, higher than FS. Other than that, it comes down to length (RS is much, much shorter and doesn't have side stuff like eggs) and setting/plot, which involves a young girl finding love with a fancy man. If you've been through Faerie Solitaire and want more hot solitaire action, this is a perfectly fine place to get it.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

The year is 1812, the place is England. Great Britain is once again at war with America. I don't believe this ever mentioned. Maybe it was. Whatever. If you want war talk, go play the Downton Abbey solitaire game, you ungrateful monster.

This is a game where you play as Bella, an ugly boy in drag who wants to marry a fancy man. Your brother somehow gambled away all of the family's money, I guess because your father fronted him his inheritance. There is a neighbor man who is interested in you despite the fact that you have no money and are an unattractive boy. You're not interested in this man because he is boring and you are unfamiliar with the saying "beggars can't be choosers." You go to stay with your Godmother who is at a places where balls are. Dancing balls. And man balls. This is a game about finding love, after all. You also have an Uncle George, who looks very old-timey British.

You are in love with Henry, a man who loves ugly boys. Your brother continues to be garbage. You have a sister, Charlotte, who is much more attractive than you, but every one is too polite to mention this. Gameplay is seamless integrated with the plot. Someone will say something like, "We should throw a ball for Bella!" and then you are playing solitaire. Upgrades come in the form of decorations for your body (clothes) and for your ballroom that seems to travel with you. No one thinks that maybe the family's money issues could be solved by maybe not building a mobile ballroom and maybe not hiring piano and harp players because #yolo.

In all seriousness, if you like Faerie Solitaire (the gold standard of solitaire games that you're kind of embarassed to play) you'll most likely enjoy Regency Solitaire as well. It's basically the same game. You have a card and you need to click on a card that's higher or lower. You want to clear the board or come as close to it as possible. Each chapter has a set of goals you must achiever. Like in Faerie Solitaire, you can get wild number cards (however, you may not collect one of each, but you can get face cards and there are true wild cards which can act as any card), you can purchase upgrades and you can build up combos.

What's different? Levels have star ratings. A perfect is three stars, but if you're close you might get one or two stars. When a combo is over it is added to a gold multiplier that last the whole level (but not the chapter). You have three power-ups that do various things and are recharged by making matches. Also, in Regency Solitaire the cards are often at goofy angles like sideways or upside down. I'm sure this is a metaphor for emotions, but it's kind of annoying, especially with that whole 6 and 9 thing.

A great thing is in Regency Solitaire, you can retry individual hands without restarting the chapter. However, if you're OCD and feel compelled to get a perfect on every level you will have to find a way to cope with the shame of seeing the "NO STARS" ranking. Otherwise, you will be forever retrying and you will be trapped in the insidious Venus flytrap that is this game

Another noticeable different feature is that if you skip over a card that can be played, the card you could have used on the board will shake. This happens even on hard mode. It's kind of nice, but if you bought Regency Solitaire hoping for a hardcore challenge, then. . .I don't. . .maybe talk to a doctor, because you might be having a stroke.

If you like Faerie Solitaire and you're not ashamed to be playing an ugly boy-centric prequel to Downton Abbey, it's a fine game. Faerie Solitaire might be a little better, it has challenges, it has the eggs that will ruin your life if you want to 100% the game, there's just a little bit more. If you've had your fill, Regency Solitaire is more than adequate. Maybe get it when it's on sale.

This is an absolutely charming game. The music is light and pretty, it has a paper doll element that also grants in-game bonus', and it has just enough challenge to keep your brain engaged but not so intense that you couldn't multitask between plays.

16390211.review:
It's like if Jane Austen made Faerie Solitaire.

Set during the Regency era in the UK, you play solitaire through a romance story set in sumptuous manors in the English countryside. The solitaire is solid, and there are lots of obstacles and power-ups to keep the game fresh as you progress through the story. Winning hands earns you cash as you progress through the game, allowing you to decorate your manor for a fancy ball. Each of the items you purchase can be used to remove cards, speed up wild card appearance, etc. With a hard and easy mode and lots of twists to the standard solitaire game, Regency Solitaire is pretty challenging and hard to stop playing.

The art is pretty and fits the setting well, but I wish the game supported higher resolutions. 

Basically, if you enjoyed Faerie Solitaire, this offers a very similar experience with a very different theme.

16349412.review:
I have played solitaire for a vast majority of my life. First, I played in the analog world with a standard deck of cards, then on various computers throughout the years. I've played several different versions from Tri-Peaks to Klondike, Clock to Free Cell. While the majority of these games started with poor graphics and standard mechanics, they eventually grew out of their shells, and became art unto themselves.

All of these games pale in comparison with Regency Solitaire. It is steeped in theme, accompanied by wonderful music, paired with a love story, and it has gorgeous artwork. I can’t help but think that this storyline somehow follows the love between the dev and his wife (or I at least imagine that it does).

I have not completed the game by any means but I urge anyone who is into solitaire games to buy and download this game at their earliest convenience! It is a wonderful treasure in a sea of now sub-par solitaire games and I can’t look back at the drivel that I once thought wonderful.

Goodbye Spider, Free Cell, Klondike, and all the rest. Regency Solitaire has it and much, much more. That thumbs up underneath this text box is not enough of a recommendation.

16106279.review: Utterly absorbing! Regency Solitaire has it all: A delightful aesthetic, great sound & music, and engaging gameplay. 16038232.review:
Just so you know: Buy this game if you want to play a version of solitaire. 

The rules of the game are well constructed, it is well balanced and has varying scenarios and goals (in the range of its self-set limitations) - it can definitely hook you in a "one more turn" sense. 
Everything else about the game is pretty poor, including the writing. Nothing is offensively bad, so as it would distract you from playing the game but it won't get any better than you not minding what happens. There's basically no animation, the game won't support your native resolution, the writing is bland and deals exclusively in stereotypes (unless there is some crazy shift in writing at the end of the game). 
Comparatively, you can do a lot better for 10€ (in terms of depth, polish and so on). If you want a relaxing game that payed its dues on carrot on stick type hooks, this is for you.

16024894.review: A very interesting way to experience solitaire. The music and artwork are very relaxing and the gameplay is challenging and fun in the right amounts.

16022022.review: A review on Rock,Paper,Shotgun piqued my interest in this game.  Something very different from my normal sort of gaming.  I was pleasantly surprised; this is a polished game combining gorgeous variations of solitaire in a Pride and Prejudice setting.  The story writing is excellent, I look forward to seeing the next part of it unfold even when I know what the ending is going to be. The game play is casual and relaxing on Normal difficulty, I haven't tried the next level but I want to.  There are some tactics to consider but it's cards right so there's a lot of luck involved.  Also, support is great, when I had an issue getting the game going, the dev came back to me very quickly and his first suggestion sorted the problem.  Recommend as a casual, relaxing game and a treat for Jane Austen fans.

16012745.review: regency solitaire is a master piece nothing can compare to this game it is that good

15990947.review:
This game is very simple, but it sucks you in. I am generally not a player of casual-type games, but this game turned out to be excellent fun. The music is amazing, the art is pretty pleasant - especially the backdrops. The gameplay might raise some questions, since it starts giving you quite steep challenges (beating this game on Hard basically requires you to get the hardest achievements... such as a 35-hit combo and a 5x multiplier), yet it is heavily randomized. But let me assure you: it is just controlled enough so that you can actually influence your own luck and pull off some great combinations. Sure, it's not as in-depth as some other games where you need to find patterns in heavily randomized sets of objects, and it's maybe a bit more reliant on the randomness than those, and you might need to grind (for jokers) a tiny bit, but it's satisfying as heck in the end.

TL;DR: simple, pleasant, satisfying. Recommended for simple fun.
